newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SASOL'S NEW ACID PLANT COMMISSIONED.
newsitem.headline: SASOL'S NEW ACID PLANT COMMISSIONED.

text.p: Sasol Solvents, a division of Sasol Chemical Industries Ltd, has commissioned a plant to extract and purify acetic acid and propionic acid, the company said on Sunday.
The plant, which will have the capacity to produce about 16,000 tonnes of acetic acid and 7,000 tonnes of propionic acid annually, represents a capital investment of 167 million rand ($37 million).
Most of the acid production will be exported offshore.
The aqueous stream emanating from the Synthol process of Sasol Synthetic Fuels at Secunda contains commercially viable amounts of acetic acid and propionic acid, the company said.
Until recently these acids were treated in a biological plant. They are now being extracted, purified and marketed by Sasol Solvents.
Acetic acid is used mainly to manufacture solvent acetates, as well as for the production of cellulose acetate, vinyl acetate, monochlor acetic acid and food additives.

Propionic acid is used for producing calcium propionate -- a new-generation mould-inhibitor in bread -- and as a preservative for stored wheat and animal feeds. It is also a feedstock for producing some polymers, herbicides and pharmaceuticals.
